Introduction:
The electricity sector accounts for 24% of global emissions, while the energy sector accounts for 73% (Our World in Data, 2021; Climate Watch, 2021; World Resources Institute, 2020). Renewable energy sources (RES) play a crucial role in mitigating climate change. RES can also help reduce emissions in other sectors through sector coupling, such as using electric vehicles in transportation or electric boilers and heat pumps in the heat sector. Data on RES generation is essential for addressing climate change.

RES generation data are used in various contexts, including studies on the technical and economic feasibility of RES expansion, short-term energy production prediction, and optimal control or efficient use of electricity in different sectors. Improving the quality of these data ensures greater accuracy and consistency in research, opening new avenues for future innovations.

Several electricity time series have been made publicly available, such as the PJM data (PJM data miner, 2021) in the US and the ENTSO-E transparency platform (ENTSO-E, 2021) in Europe. However, compiling data for a large number of electricity production units, including small generation like rooftop solar plants, is challenging and results in time series with many missing values. For instance, the ENTSO-E transparency platform has an average of 1000 missing values per week in the production mix data for 2015 and 2016 (Hirth et al., 2018).

(Ruggles et al., 2020) show that even after filling gaps in electricity demand time series, the results of a power system model can vary by 5% between using two sophisticated data imputation approaches, even for a simple analysis considering only one region. They also show that simple data imputation methods produce unacceptable results.

In this work, we fill the data gaps in the ENTSO-E transparency platform data, which consists of 32 regions (European countries), and fill gaps in electricity demand, wind and solar generation, and electricity prices time series. Time series literature has used various methods for data imputation, mostly based on statistical correlation and regression techniques (Van Buuren, 2018). Recent advances in Machine and Deep Learning suggest that sequence prediction and forecasting methods can be applied to imputation of missing values in energy data (Wang et al., 2019).

Recurrent Neural Networks (RNNs) and Long-Short Term Memory (LSTMs) networks have been applied to forecast electricity production from renewable energy sources and electricity demand, and to fill in missing values (Liu et al., 2019; Kumar et al., 2018). In recent years, transformers have become the preferred architecture for processing sequences in natural language processing applications. Transformers use an attention mechanism to identify relevant fragments in a sequence, learning dependencies between all considered time stamps explicitly.

In an electricity system, there are high dependencies between electricity generation, demand, and price time series. For example, the dispatch of different power generation technologies depends on the dispatch of competing technologies. The sum of electricity generation must match electricity demand, taking into account storage technologies. Additionally, electricity prices in each hour depend on the dispatch of electricity generation.
